item.title: Productivity Being the Modern BS
item.description:
Hugely influenced and inspired by Our Productivity Obsession

Productivity takes root from a set of Assumptions

  • Being more productive improve quality of life
  • Some random dudes from the internet know how to make you productive
  • You don't know how to be productive

Productivity-related materials, despite being in multiple forms: videos, podcasts, written words, can be categorized into 2 main groups based on their 'natures'.

  1. Motivational materials
  2. Informative materials

And we shall discuss their flaws one by one

To do xyz, first you need to be motivated

If you have achieved anything, naming those insignificant ones, such as throwing the rubbish in the nearby recycling station, you normally know how to repeat your actions(ofc). For those actions that we carried out routinely, we form habits out of it. We don't need motivation to do those.

For more difficult tasks, naming those you don't perceive them as entertainment, non-routines, you need to have good justification for yourself to do these tasks. If you know it is important and urgent, you might just do it in order to avoid consequences. However, for those without clear deadlines, reaching a higher level of 'Activational Energy' become much difficult.

It is alright though, since the stuff that need to be done, should be done naturally one way or another. Not for those cannot be done, however.

xyz need motivational videos, since he

  1. Doesn't have the 'Activational Energy' required to do abc
  2. Doesn't have good causes for doing abc
  3. Doesn't think it is important and urgent to do abc
  4. Doesn't think abc could be done unless you are 'better'

No motivational videos are featuring the current you, they are featuring the people who are 'better', more educated, more insightful, richer, stronger, or simply more angry.

By opting for lays down and watches that gray-scale video until Uncle Gary finished his speech, you truly believe that you can be 'better' or having more 'willpowers' to do xyz, to a degree that the lost hours that you tore your hearts off, can easily be compensated by the future you working harder than ever.

Right?

Someone else knows me better

Of course this is sometimes the case. Being a extremely subjective entity, a person could not see his flaws easily. That's why we need to 'be an observer', judging ourself in a objective manner.(ofc again)

It's easily the case when someone, especially those acclaimed figures, to be more objectively productive than you or to be more knowledgeable than you. By opting for lays down and watches that animated drawing video with cringy cartoon, you truly believe that you can learn something you don't already know about 'productivity' and 'working hard', and you wholeheartedly believe that the morning-routine of anut Michelle can be copied roughly to fit your lifestyle and quirks. (Let's us at least assume that what they tell you is real and those rituals are actually productive.)

More than nothing huh?

This is just a start

It is not your faults evolving from binge-watching-netflix normie to binge-watching-youtube chad. No one could give you gold nuggets if they don't have any, not one could have any gold nuggets unless there is a magical gold mine in San Francisco.

Why do they put out those contents?

  1. Frick yes, I just learnt from personal experience that doing abc is better than doing xyz
  2. I just want to be somewhat influential and successful
  3. People like these types of contents, so I make them, and I could sell my merch, books, online courses whatever

Undoubtedly, our lovely economy awards those people who create viral contents monetarily. Those full of rhetorics, competitive 'content-creators' could lose their market values easily, and that's basically their motivation and incentive behind all of the works they devoted their time to.

The business model of productivity contents boils down to acquiring your time and attention, give you some seemingly great contents so that you feel good about yourself, then rip the poop out of you by selling stuff and hosting VPNs' ads. Such business model fuels their gut to constantly create 'better' videos to buy their groceries and pay for Youtube Premium.

To the consumers, it is a bad news. Since what you perfer is 'one-video-to-rule-them-all', not the daily update on 'how-to-be-productive-for-the-next-2-hours'. The more time and money you spend on contents, more you may be lucky enough to hear something astounding, at the same time more addicted to nonsense and less time for actually doing 'the work'.

I don't trust you, don't forget you are also just a random guy from the internet, who may be writing this for ill purposes. And you have poor grammar.

You shouldn't all of what I just said and my grammar is poor. But at least you could learn some Economics101.

Opportunity Cost is defined as the highest-valued option forgone.

Opportunity Cost = Time Cost + Money Cost.

When you are watching the same productivity video over and over again, be sure to have nothing more valuable to do.

Notorious Law of DMR - Diminishing Marginal Returns states that as you increase the some means of production(in this case, time), the output of a production process decreases.

Just think of it as: more stuff you consooooomed, less stuff you get.

Ok you shall close this tab now.(by RSS Gang)
